Summary Expert in MEMS (MicroElectroMechanical Systems), microfluidics, silicon sensors and actuators for biomedical use and severe environments. Experience in instrument development for analytical chemistry including gas chromatography and liquid chromatography, with familiarity-by-exposure to mass spectrography, DNA sequencing, microfluidics, and medtech. Broad knowledge of materials and packaging techniques for circuits and sensors, including silicon fusion bonding and transient liquid phase bonding. Master Research Scientist, Agilent Labs Agilent Technologies November 1999  –  January 2015  (15 years 3 months) Santa Clara, California (Agilent Labs began as a part of HP Labs and became a separate lab as Agilent spun out from Hewlett-Packard in 1999.) 
 
● Developed detectors for gas chromatography systems. 
● Developed microfluidic switching systems for optical crosspoint switching. 
● Fabricated and tested synthetic nanopores for long-strand DNA translocation aimed at the "thousand-dollar-genome" sequencing effort. 
● Worked on ultra-high-pressure microfluidics for liquid chromatography. Master Research Scientist, HP Labs Hewlett-Packard November 1989  –  November 1999  (10 years 1 month) Palo Alto, California ● Designed and built silicon microvalves for gas chromatography systems. 
● Improved air management for inkjet deposition systems. 
● Developed massively parallel ink jet deposition systems for cDNA deposition. 
● With Kaigham Gabriel (at that time at DARPA), briefed Secretary of Defense William Perry on MEMS (MicroElectricoMechanical Systems) at Perry's Pentagon office. May 1995. Vice President/Chief Scientist NovaSensor (now part of Amphenol Advanced Sensors) January 1986  –  November 1989  (3 years 11 months) Fremont, CA Semiconductor sensor and actuator design, layout, fabrication, and packaging in a startup environment. 
 
● Developed piezoresistive pressure sensors and accelerometers, silicon microvalves. Approximately 31 designs were put into production over 4 years.  
● Pioneered silicon fusion bonding for sensors. 
● Pioneered ion implanted resistors for pressure sensors. 
● Developed a general-purpose instant-on-stability design and process for piezoresistive pressure sensors.  
● Developed dielectrically isolated high-temperature pressure sensors.  
● Developed high-dynamic range ultrasonic pressure sensors.  
● Developed ultra-high-pressure piezoresistive pressure sensors for blast measurement. 
● Developed a piezoresistive accelerometer with bi-directional mechanical over-range stops. Senior Research Associate Stanford University January 1980  –  January 1986  (6 years 1 month) Developed silicon sensors for biomedical and robotics applications 
 
● Developed piezoresistive pressure sensors packaged for in-vivo use. 
● Used piezoresistive pressure sensors to measure in-tissue pressures in a pig model to characterize pressures characteristic of bedsore development in humans. 
● Developed linear thermometer arrays on flexible polyimide ribbons for measurement of temperature profiles during hyperthermia treament of cancor tumors. 
● Developed an early attempt at "robot skin": Flexible polyimide sheets with embedded force sensors. 
● Co-authored a 1984 Scientific American article on silicon micromachining technology for sensors and analytical instruments. Summary While most people can claim depth to their experience and education within their discipline, I am better characterized by breadth across disciplines as well as depth within. I am truly transdiciplinary with an undergraduate degree in Computer Science and doctoral degree in Genetics, 6 years of professional programming experience accumulated between these degrees and significant coursework and experience in statistics throughout my career.  
 
My strongest skill and experience is high performance computing and novel algorithm development working with massive datasets that pose many technical challenges in addition to just their sheer size. Strong programming skills in C, multithreaded parallelizaton, MPI, and more recently developing skills in GP-GPU programming, has enabled a great deal of my Ph.D. work in genomics to be successful as well as that following as a Research Associate at Cornell University.  
 
I am often the problem solver in a group environment as a direct result of having a broad educational background and work experience to draw on, but also from having many ideas to offer. The best way to stumble on a great idea is to have a lot of them. I also often function as a "translator" between different disciplines as much of the current projects I work on employ people highly specialized in one of molecular biology, quantitative genetics, population genetics, statistics, computer science (programming), information technology (infrastructure), and information management (database administration) and I have some experience in all of these areas, and significant experience in programming, statistics, population genetics, quantitative genetics, and information technology infrastructure. Experience Senior Research Associate Stanford University School of Medicine August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) Stanford, California I am currently working on developing further computational methods for resolving local ancestry in admixed populations, building on methods previously developed in Carlos Bustamante's group at Stanford. The methodology is based on machine learning techniques, specifically a random forest classifier combined with maximizing the conditional random field over the random forest classification probabilities for discrete windows across the genome of fixed genetic size. Primary goals are to improve scalability of the method to very large datasets in terms of both markers and individuals, and to improve usability for both users at large and users internal to our group. Secondary goals, being pursued in tandem, are to refine accuracy and sensitivity and perform extensive validation of the program. 
 
I am also interested in recently developed long read high throughput sequencing and exploring pilot datasets as they become available to the lab. The pros and cons of different approaches coming to market are not clear and depend on the use case. My work currently involves data from an early, low coverage variant of the moleculo synthetic long read technology but is expanding in the near future to newer technologies and higher sequencing depths as costs continue to decrease. Research Associate (Academic) Cornell University May 2010  –  July 2014  (4 years 3 months) Ithaca, New York Area Supervisor: Susan R. McCouch 
 
* Development of novel algorithms, methods, programs, pipelines, and statistical models to solve the unique challenges of several projects in this position, some of which listed below 
* Development of a High Density Rice Array (HDRA) targeting over 1 million SNPs segregating in cultivated and wild Asian and African rice populations, featuring a novel internal control mechanism for accuracy estimation & sample QC, methylation targets, and invariant probes for normalization and copy number variation detection.  
* SNP discovery through pooled data generation from an ad hoc consortium backing the development of the HDRA described above. Challenges posed by unexpected very high diversity levels and subpopulation divergence forced development of more sensitive next generation sequencing analysis tools than available at the time 
* Development of smaller, "breeder's chips" - 384 Illumina BeadExpress arrays and more recently a 6K bead chip replacing legacy chips and providing expanded mapping resolution to a broader range of germplasm 
* Analysis of rice subpopulation structure, evolution, and domestication 
* Integration of genome local subpopulation information into genotyping calling methods and GWAS analyses 
* Broad support of the group's Genome Wide Association Mapping analyses through development of the genotyping technologies, primary genomics analysis methods (genotype calling), dataset management, and support of personnel long term responsible for data versioning, archiving, and distribution. 
* Concept development for grants and publications 
* General troubleshooting efforts and problem solving across many projects throughout the broader research group 
* Genotype-by-sequencing analysis methodology and development 
* Extensive IT duties to support all of this work Graduate Student Cornell University 2004  –  2010  (6 years) Ithaca, New York Area Adviser & Committee Chair: Carlos D. Bustamante 
 
As a graduate student I did much the same type of research that I am now doing as a research associate, but in addition I also worked with several systems other than rice including human, cattle, dogs, and drosophila (fruit flies). In the first few years I spent some time at the lab bench learning molecular biology techniques. Gaining a background in this area has served me well in working together with experimentalists and molecular biologists while myself being primarily a computational biologist and high performance programmer handling very large genomic datasets. Often the people specializing in each of these fields can not communicate effectively between disciplines because neither side understands the complexity of the other. A primary goal for me in going to graduate school in genetics while coming from a computer science and professional programming background was to gain the ability to bridge this gap. This goal was certainly achieved as it is now one of my primary functions in my current position as a researcher at Cornell. Programmer/Analyst researcher Cornell University 2001  –  2004  (3 years) Ithaca, New York Area Supervisor: Steven D. Tanksley 
 
I was first exposed to Biology and Bioinformatics in this position, previously having no knowledge or experience whatsoever. My interest in genetics and genomics developed here and motivated me to go to graduate school to build a broader background and to explore my own research interests more deeply. Work for this position fell largely into two categories: (1) website and database programming, development, and integration, and (2) development of continually improving methods for assemblies of EST sequences into unigene (contig) sequences. The database I developed, and its web interface, tracked all data from physical location of a cDNA clone in a freezer to every chromatogram generated, base calling sequence of that chromatogram, and every version of a unigene build as well as annotations of that sequence which followed. This became the basis of the SOL genomics network (http://solgenomics.net/) and much of what I developed is still present and functional on the present day site. Additional duties involved all system and network administration for both the bioinformatics group and the computer needs of the larger wet lab researchers. Programmer Strategic Forecasting May 1998  –  January 2001  (2 years 9 months) Ithaca, New York Area • Development, optimization, and maintenance of CORSIM, a dynamic microsimulation of the United States population for policy research. Model written in C with speed and memory efficiency a primary goal as hardware limitations largely dictated the size and complexity of the simulations we could run 
• Developed programs and tools for the automated analysis of the extensive output produced 
by the simulation - 50-100 GB, a lot of data for the time especially for PC class hardware 
• Worked extensively with other programmers and analysts on the development of modules in 
addition to the core demographic model such as the modeling of family itemized wealth 
accumulation and inheritance, US Social Security Law, and proposed reform policies. 
• Worked with the Canadian Government on the adoption of the core model and its 
adaptation to Canadian populations and utility in simulating the Canadian Pension Plan 
(Canadian equivalent of US Social Security). 
• Main communications person between programmers and code developers and data analysts, 
having worked on both sides of the project extensively. 
• Frequently called upon to solve crises or time critical items arising on either analysis or 
programming/debugging sides of the project

Summary My current position is Senior Research Associate in the Radiological Sciences Laboratory in the Department of Radiology at Stanford School of Medicine. I provide hardware, systems, and general technical support for a group of 11 Faculty members and many students and post docs in the development of advanced medical imaging and image guided interventions. My training background is primarily in RF and electrical engineering and I spent more than 25 years in the commercial diagnostic imaging industry. Most of the projects I am currently working on involve high field MRI (3 Tesla and above), Magnetic Resonance Guided Focused Ultrasound, and other hybrid systems involving ultrasound imaging, therapeutic ultrasound combined with MRI. I have ongoing collaborations with many other medical research institutes and Universities around the world. I currently have 39 issued US patents

Summary I am a self-motivated, hard-working person with strong research and laboratory management skills. I've worked in many different sectors, including academia, government labs, and industry. I also love to teach, specifically at the community college level. 
 
My extensive laboratory experience includes knowledge of molecular and cell biology, live virus work, immunohistochemistry, synthetic biology, cell and tissue culture, microscopy, sequencing, and basic bioinformatics. I also have experience in setting up new and transitioning labs. 
 
Specialties: Specialization in Cell & Molecular Biology, Synthetic Biology, Cell Culture and Infectious Disease. Strong knowledge in virology, parasitology, pathogenesis, epidemiology, life support systems for long duration space exploration, resource recovery, sustainable and closed-loop technologies, and public health. I am working to integrate biological processes into current and advanced life support systems for deep space missions at NASA Ames Research Center. Dr. Watson received the award for his leadership and distinguished contributions in the areas of vision science and human factors. ARVO Gold Fellow Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology January 2012 The title of ARVO Fellow is an honor established to recognize current ARVO members for their individual accomplishments, leadership and contributions to the Association. 
 
ARVO Fellows serve as role models and mentors for individuals pursuing careers in vision and ophthalmology research and help further ARVO's vision ”… to facilitate the advancement of vision research and the prevention and cure of disorders of the visual system worldwide”, which includes advancing basic and clinical knowledge and serving as the leading international forum for vision research and the primary advocate for vision science worldwide. Otto Schade Prize Society for Information Display February 2007 The Otto Schade Prize in Display Performance and Image Quality is awarded for an outstanding scientific or technical achievement in, or contribution to, the advancement of functional performance and/or image quality of information displays. Dr. Watson's citation reads: "For his many contributions to vision science and the computational modeling of the visual process, including applications to display and image quality metrics and image compression." Summary A performance-driven Research scientist with management skills and expertise in molecular virology including viral replication assays, genetic analysis of viral genomes and cell biology. Research focus on hepatitis viruses including HCV, HAV and HDV. Proven ability to work on multiple projects independently and in a team environment with understanding of the scientific field in a business environment. Desire a leading and challenging position to utilize my vast experience in molecular virology toward drug discovery effort in leading biopharmaceutical company. 
 
Qualifications Summary: 
• Adopt new research concepts and ideas in a competitive 
research field and generate innovative findings in a short 
period of time. 
• Identify and validate new potential antiviral target and its  
potential to serve as a target. 
• Manage collaborative projects in matrix environment between 
academic labs and biotech companies while adhering to 
project timelines. 
• Demonstrate ability to work individually and as part of a team 
in a constructive and productive manner and assume a  
leading role when necessary. 
• Experienced in a range of molecular virology methodologies  
using various viral replication systems (HCV, HDV, HAV,  
vaccinia). 
• Experienced in identifying viral-resistance development in  
response to antiviral drug treatment in culture systems. 
• Experienced in cell culture methodologies and primary culture 
establishment. 
• Establish and optimize a cell-based assay for drug discovery  
effort in collaboration with Stanford’s high-throughput facility. Specialties:Molecular Virology  
HCV, HAV, HDV and other viruses

Affiliated Scientist Molecular Sciences Institute 2015  – Present (less than a year) Milpitas, CA The Molecular Sciences Institute (MSI) is an independent, non-profit research laboratory and a 501(c)(3) organization. 
Our mission is to integrate science across many disciplines in order to make radical leaps in knowledge that leads to real impact in the world.  
 
Within this grand challenge, we have two, intertwined goals.  
•	Perform cutting-edge science within our not-for-profit institute. 
•	Provide a "Proving Ground" for the next generation of entrepreneurs and scientists to help them achieve their maximum potential. 
 
http://www.molsci.org Docent / Associate Professor Uppsala University 2014  – Present (1 year) Department of Chemistry - BMC Board Member The Swedish-American Chamber of Commerce - San Francisco/Silicon Valley March 2015  – Present (6 months) SACC-USA is the umbrella organization for 18 regional Swedish-American Chambers of Commerce across the United States. The organization serves more than 2,300 members in Sweden and the U.S., which makes SACC-USA the second largest European Chamber of Commerce in the United States. 
 
The mission of SACC is to facilitate and support trade, commerce, and investment between the U.S. and Sweden. SACC help Swedish companies find the right partners in the USA – and vice versa. By using a wide network and contact generating tools and methods, the organization ensures that products, services and information are presented in the right way to the right people. President, Silicon Vikings Stockholm Chapter Silicon Vikings January 2012  –  June 2013  (1 year 6 months) Stockholm, Sweden We are the Swedish Chapter to Silicon Vikings HQ, a collaborative non-profit member organization for networking and promotion of technologies and businesses intersecting Silicon Valley (San Francisco Bay Area, California, U.S.A.) and the Nordic region (Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden). Silicon Vikings delivers value to its members through technology and business driven events, projects and social networking events. We connect the Nordic Region to Silicon Valley's networked business and educational ecosystems. The University of Texas at Austin Post Doc,  Chemical Engineering 1997  – 1998 Advisor: Prof. Keith P. Johnston, Dept. of Chemical Engineering.  
Phase behaviour and design of new surfactants for water/carbon dioxide microemulsions and emulsions. Demonstrated their use in a new route for synthetic organic chemistry as they facilitate reactions between organic substrates and hydrophilic nucleophiles to a much greater degree than conventional microemulsions in organic solvents. Lowered the surfactant concentration by an order of magnitude compared to the case of microemulsions in organic solvents and achieved comparable product yields. Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, USA Post Doc,  Chemsitry 1998  – 2000 Advisor: William Tumas, CST-18.  
Homogeneous biphasic catalysis in water/carbon dioxide (c/w) microemulsions and emulsions. Demonstrated improved reaction rates, phase separation and reuse of catalyst and surfactant, and extended applications to non water-soluble substrates for homogeneous catalysis using the biphasic c/w systems as compared to conventional biphasic systems. Patent filed on these findings. Summary I co-founded and direct the digital arts minor at Dartmouth College. Our undergraduate program merges computer science, visual arts, animation and engineering. Students take computer modeling, computer animation, programming for interactive digital arts, projects in digital arts, motion studies courses and more. Our Digital Arts Creative Technology Studio is a vibrant place where students from all disciplines and backgrounds work together, using best practices in technology, art and science to solve complex problems, make interactive art, build tools and visualize data. Summary My 25 year career in policy development, idea generation and thought leadership is characterized by using well-grounded evidence and communication tools to drive impact. Through in-depth analysis, planning and team management, I advance strategic ideas while working collaboratively with key stakeholders. Areas of expertise include policy implementation and effectiveness, educational reform, and post-secondary attainment. Teaching and research associations over the past 20 years include Stanford University, University of Minnesota and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. I hold a Ph. D. and M.A. from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, B.A. from Lawrence University, and a certificate from Harvard University's Kennedy School for Executive Education. 
 
Specialties: Social science/education research, project management, idea generation of public value, public speaking, technical writing. Through in-depth analysis, planning and team management, I advance strategic ideas while working collaboratively with key stakeholders. Areas of expertise include policy implementation and effectiveness, educational reform, and post-secondary attainment. Teaching and research associations over the past 20 years include Stanford University, University of Minnesota and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. I hold a Ph. D. and M.A. from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, B.A. from Lawrence University, and a certificate from Harvard University's Kennedy School for Executive Education.
